skill.name: doc-coauthoring
skill.description: Guide users through a structured workflow for co-authoring documentation. Use when user wants to write documentation, proposals, technical specs, decision docs, or similar structured content. This workflow helps users efficiently transfer context, refine content through iteration, and verify the doc works for readers. Trigger when user mentions writing docs, creating proposals, drafting specs, or similar documentation tasks.

security_audit.summary: Official Anthropic skill containing only procedural workflow instructions for document co-authoring. No code execution, file system access, or external integrations beyond standard Claude capabilities.

content.value_statement: A guided three-stage workflow that helps you create high-quality documentation through structured context gathering, iterative refinement, and reader testing to ensure your docs actually work for their intended audience.
actual_capabilities: Guides users through structured context gathering with clarifying questions
Supports integration with tools like Slack, Teams, Google Drive, and SharePoint for context pulling
Brainstorms 5-20 content options per section based on gathered context
Iteratively refines document sections through surgical edits
Tests documents with fresh Claude instances to catch blind spots and ambiguities
Works with artifacts or file-based workflows depending on environment
Adapts to different document types (PRDs, RFCs, technical specs, decision docs)
Generates alt-text for images in shared documents for accessibility
limitations: Requires user engagement throughout the three-stage process
Reader testing with sub-agents only available in environments like Claude Code
Integration features depend on user having enabled appropriate connectors
May take longer than freeform writing for simple documents
Requires user to provide substantial context upfront for best results

use_cases.title: Technical Specification Writing
use_cases.description: Engineers can use this workflow to write comprehensive technical specs that effectively communicate architecture decisions, implementation details, and trade-offs to their team and stakeholders.

use_cases.title: Product Requirement Documents
use_cases.description: Product managers can create clear PRDs that capture user needs, feature requirements, and success metrics while ensuring all stakeholders understand the proposal.

use_cases.title: Decision Documentation
use_cases.description: Team leads can document important decisions including context, alternatives considered, and rationale in a way that helps future readers understand why choices were made.

use_cases.title: RFC and Proposal Writing
use_cases.description: Contributors can draft well-structured RFCs that effectively communicate proposed changes, gather feedback, and build consensus across distributed teams.

prompt_templates.title: Start a Technical Spec
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to write a technical spec for [project/feature name]. Can you guide me through the doc co-authoring workflow?
prompt_templates.scenario: When starting a new technical specification document

prompt_templates.title: Create a Decision Doc
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me create a decision doc about [decision topic]. I want to make sure it captures all the context and trade-offs.
prompt_templates.scenario: When documenting an important architectural or product decision

prompt_templates.title: Draft a Proposal
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to write a proposal for [initiative]. Can we use the structured workflow to make sure it's clear and comprehensive?
prompt_templates.scenario: When proposing a new initiative or major change

prompt_templates.title: Write an RFC
prompt_templates.prompt: I want to draft an RFC for [feature/change]. Let's use the co-authoring workflow to make sure I cover everything.
prompt_templates.scenario: When creating a request for comments document

output_examples.input: I need to write a design doc for our new authentication system
output_examples.output:
I can guide you through a structured workflow for co-authoring this design doc. We'll work through three stages:

1. **Context Gathering**: You'll provide context while I ask clarifying questions
2. **Refinement & Structure**: We'll iteratively build each section through brainstorming and editing
3. **Reader Testing**: We'll test the doc with a fresh Claude to catch blind spots

This ensures your doc works well when others read it. Would you like to try this workflow, or prefer to work freeform?

best_practices: Start with the section that has the most unknowns (usually the core proposal or technical approach)
Provide context in whatever format is easiest - stream of consciousness, links to channels, shared documents
Use shorthand when answering clarifying questions to move faster
Indicate specific changes rather than editing directly to help Claude learn your style
Test documents with Reader Claude before sharing with actual stakeholders
Link the co-authoring conversation in an appendix for transparency
Use appendices for depth without bloating the main document
Do a final read-through yourself before considering the doc complete
anti_patterns: Skipping context gathering and jumping straight to drafting
Providing minimal context and expecting Claude to fill in gaps
Making direct edits to the document instead of indicating changes
Rushing through reader testing or skipping it entirely
Using the workflow for very simple, straightforward documents
Not verifying facts, links, or technical details in the final review

faq.question: When should I use this workflow vs. writing freeform?
faq.answer: Use this workflow for substantial documentation like technical specs, PRDs, decision docs, or RFCs where clarity for readers is critical. For simple documents or quick write-ups, freeform writing is faster and more appropriate.

faq.question: Can I skip stages or modify the workflow?
faq.answer: Yes, you have full agency to adjust the process. If a stage doesn't make sense for your document, you can skip it or work freeform. The workflow is a guide, not a requirement.

faq.question: What if I don't have integrations enabled for Slack or Google Drive?
faq.answer: You can still use the workflow - just paste relevant content directly into the chat instead of pulling it from connected tools. In claude.ai or the Claude app, you can enable connectors in settings to allow direct integration access.

faq.question: How does reader testing work?
faq.answer: In environments like Claude Code, reader testing uses a fresh Claude instance with no context from your conversation to answer questions about your doc. In other environments like claude.ai, you'll manually test by opening a new conversation and asking the questions.

faq.question: Should I use artifacts or files?
faq.answer: The workflow automatically adapts - it uses artifacts if available (like in claude.ai) or creates markdown files in environments without artifacts (like Claude Code). Both approaches work equally well.

faq.question: How long does this workflow typically take?
faq.answer: It depends on document complexity and how much context needs to be gathered. The workflow prioritizes quality over speed - the goal is a document that actually works for readers, which saves time in the long run by reducing confusion and follow-up questions.
